title: Rebel Wilson joins Avengers' Scarlett Johansson at JoJo Rabbit premiere
text:
Rebel Wilson is lady in red (Picture: Rex)

Rebel Wilson was the ultimate lady in red as she joined Avengers star Scarlett Johansson at the Los Angeles premiere for JoJo Rabbit.

The duo, who will be appearing alongside each other in the highly anticipated movie, posed up a storm on the red carpet as they beamed at the cameras.

Giggling away to one another, the pair appeared to be in high spirits as they enjoyed the lavish evening.

Scarlett had opted to wear a bright pink two-piece to the ceremony, which had been embellished in both silver and pink diamontes.

While her co-star stunned in a berry red dress, with matching lippy.

She joined Avengers star Scarlett Johansson (Picture: Rex)

Taika Waititi posed up a storm (Picture: Splash News)

And while they worked the floor, the iconic A-listers were later pictured with the likes of Thomasin McKenzie and Taika Waititi.

The 19-year-old actress appeared to be in her element in a lime green dress, and as the trio were taking their photocall seriously, Taika ambushed the shoot where he joked around with Rebel.

Making faces down the lens, the stars could be seen having all the fun as they brought humour to the event.

Rebel was even caught holding up two fingers as her partner in crime leaned into the Pitch Perfect actress for the snap.

The duo looked like they were having the best of times (Picture: Splash News)

The cast have recently called Taika Waititi a manchild (Picture: Rex)

Among the talent were the likes of Sam Rockwell and Game Of Thrones star Alfie Allen – who sparkled in his black and silver suit.

Just recently, child actor Archie Yates spoke to Metro.co.uk about his co-stars where he called Taika a ‘manchild’ (and by the looks of these pictures, we completely believe him).

Taika, he’s the funniest guy I’ve ever met. We thought he was a manchild rather than an adult,’ he laughed.

‘But we never regretted working with Taika. He’s the best guy ever.’

While producer Carthew Neal added: ‘I trust Taika implicitly, I’ve worked with him before so I understand he knows how to work between humour and pathos and get the balance right.’
